bind.jr:constraintMsg: Maximum temperature should be less than 100
It should be less than maximum temperature
"Total Population served by the facility" should be greater than "Annual Number of Births"
Please do not enter any special character
Please enter a value between 0 to 42.
Please enter a value between 0 to 11.
Please enter a value between 0 to 42 and it must be less than total experience.
Please enter a value between 0 to 11.

Value should be positive and less than or equals to the number of freezer rooms.
Value should be positive and less than or equals to the number of cold rooms
Value should be positive and less than or equals to the number of vaccine freezers and refrigerators
Value should be positive and less than or equal to total number of refrigerators and freezers present.
Value should be positive and less than or equal to total number of refrigerators and freezers present.
Value should be positive and less than or equal to total number of ice-pack freezers/cool-pack coolers
Value should be positive and less than or equal to total number of ice-pack freezers/cool-pack coolers

input.label: Effective Vaccine Management Initiative
input.hint: EVM Assessment Tool for health facility vaccine store

select1.label: District:
Block name:

input.label: If Other, Specify the block name

select1.label: L1 - Assessment Scope

input.label: Geo point
input.hint: Please ensure that co-ordinates are captured under clear sky.

upload.label: Image 1
upload.hint: Please ensure that the name of the facility is clearly visible in the image.

upload.label: Image 2
upload.hint: Please ensure that the name of the facility is clearly visible in the image.

input.label: L2.01 Supply Chain Levels - Service Point
L2.04 - Unique code for this facility:
L2.14 - Assessed records start date
input.hint: Assessed date refers to the period of review

input.label: L2.15 - Assessed records finish date
input.hint: Assessed date refers to the period of review

input.label: L2.18- Total population (served by the facility):
L3 - Permanently employed staff in the facility
input.hint: In this section, record the specified details about the permanent employees of the facility.

group.label: L3 - Permanently employed staff in the facility

input.label: Qualifications
input.hint: Specify level of education: e.g. technical college vocational qualification, university first degree etc.

input.label: Experience
input.hint: Record previous experience in the field of vaccine management. To be specified in Years and Months (if any)

input.label: Years in post
input.hint: Record duration in the current post. To be specified in Years and Months (if any)

group.label: E0 Complete these facility specific questions before continuing.

input.label: E0:01a What type of cold chain equipment is used in the store?
input.hint: Answers to this question switch later indicators on and off.

select1.label: A. Vaccine is stored in cold room(s) and/or freezer room(s)
B. Vaccine is stored in refrigerators or long-term cold boxes
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Including solar refrigerators. 'Long-term cold box' means a device that can reliably store vaccine for over 7 days without power (PQS specification in preparation).

select1.label: C. Vaccine is stored in freezers
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Including solar freezers.

select1.label: D. Coolant-packs, including ice-packs and/or cool-packs and/or PCM-packs are prepared in the store
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Select 'Y' if there is equipment in the store used exclusively for preparing coolant-packs (ice-packs and/or cool-packs and/or PCM-packs). Ignore fridge/freezers with ice-pack compartments or freezer rooms/cold rooms that are also used to store vaccine.

select1.label: E. Vaccines are kept in standard passive containers only (cold boxes and/or vaccine carriers). There is no active refrigeration.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Some health facilities have no refrigerators and may use cold boxes or vaccine carriers to store vaccine for immunization sessions. In such cases, select 'Y' for option D and 'N' for all others.

input.label: E0:03a What type of equipment is used to deliver and/or collect vaccine at this store?

select1.label: A. Cold boxes, vaccine carriers and/or other passive containers?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Other passive containers' includes insulated roll containers or palletized containers. These may be used at primary and sub-national levels.

select1.label: B. Refrigerated vehicles?

input.label: E0:05a Specify all transport types used for vaccine delivery or collection at this level.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: List all transport types: government-operated, parastatal or private.

select1.label: A. On foot
B. Bicycles and/or motorcycles
C. Cars, vans, trucks, refrigerated trucks and other road vehicles
D. Aircraft
E. Railway
F. Boat
G. Other

group.label: E2 All vaccines & diluents are stored within WHO-recommended temperature ranges.

select1.label: E2:03a. Can the storekeeper(s) or health worker(s) give the correct storage temperature range for each of the vaccines on the schedule?
select1.hint: Guidace Notes: Knowledge of correct storage temperatures is vital. If ANY of the respondents give any incorrect answers, score 'No'. Note also: 1) If s/he says that freeze-dried vaccines should be stored at -20°C record this as 'Yes'. Current WHO advice is to store these vaccines at +2° to + 8°C, but storage at -20°C will not damage these vaccines. 2) If s/he say that freeze-dried vaccines packed with diluents can be stored at -20°C, this answer MUST be scored as 'No'. 3) At service point level, it is correct to say that all vaccines can be stored at +2° to +8°C.

select1.label: E2:04a. Do the storekeeper(s) or health worker(s) know which vaccines on the schedule can be damaged by temperatures below 0°C?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: It is essential that respondents know which of the vaccines should not be exposed to temperatures below 0°C. It is not important that they know the precise freezing temperature of each of these vaccines.

select1.label: E2:06a. Can the storekeeper or health worker demonstrate correct reading of all types of thermometer and/or temperature recording device(s) used in the store?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Ask the storekeeper or health worker to demonstrate correct practice. A stem or dial thermometer must be held correctly so as to avoid parallax errors. Interpolation of values between the printed numbers on the temperature scale must be accurate. Interpretation of readings taken from chart recorders and electronic recording devices must be correct.

input.label: E2:07b. If there is refrigeration equipment. Temperature record checklist:
input.hint: This question applies all in health facilities with active refrigeration. It does not apply in health facilities where cold boxes or vaccine carriers are used to store vaccine temporarily. Manual records are necessary because this is the only way to be sure that temperatures are checked at least twice a day. 'Complete' means that there should be no missing' record sheets or electronic temperature traces and that the entire review period should be covered for each appliance.

select1.label: A. Are refrigeration temperatures recorded manually?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Daily manual recording of the temperatures of refrigeration equipment allows the store keeper/health worker/supervisor to: a. verify whether the storage temperature is within the acceptable temperature ranges of +2°C to +8°C in cold rooms and vaccine refrigerators and - 25°C to -15°C in the freezer room and freezers, b. detect temperature alarm conditions which may have caused vaccine damage and to take appropriate action, and, c. assess the performance over time of vaccine handling at each link of the cold chain and to monitor the performance of cold chain equipment.

select1.label: B. Are the manual temperature records complete (twice daily, every day) for each and every cold room, freezer room, vaccine refrigerator and vaccine freezer throughout the review period?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Complete' means there are temperature records (AM and PM) for every day of the review period for each appliance.

select1.label: C. Does the temperature record form include space for entering alarm events?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Enter n/a if only stem or dial thermometers are used. If 30-day refrigerator loggers are used, the form must be designed to record alarm events. If the form is inadequate please comment in the Notes section.

select1.label: E2:11a. If there is refrigeration equipment. Have temperature records been kept in a safe place for at least three years?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Countries should be encouraged to retain such records for tracing purposes. If records are not available for three years, review the records kept since the immunization programme adopted EVSM or EVM.

input.label: E2:12a. If there is refrigeration equipment. Temperature and alarm event review checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: There must be a written record of these reviews which identifies problems and records actions taken. A verbal assurance is not sufficient.

select1.label: A. Are temperature records and alarm events formally reviewed at least once a month in order to identify temperature excursions and their causes?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check whether records are reviewed and recorded. 'Excursions' are temperatures below +2°C or above +8°C for cold rooms and vaccine refrigerators, and above -5°C for freezer rooms and vaccine freezers.

select1.label: B. If temperature records and alarm events are formally reviewed at least once a month, is there documentary evidence that remedial action has been taken in response to excursions or breakdowns?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Enter n/a if there are no excursions or breakdowns. Interview the responsible person. Discuss and evaluate remedial actions taken. Inspect maintenance records.

group.label: E3 Cold storage, dry storage and transport capacity is sufficient to accommodate all vaccines and supplies needed for the programme.

input.label: E3:01a. If there is refrigeration equipment. Using data from the annual vaccine arrival schedule (primary level) and the annual vaccine delivery schedule (lower levels), establish whether the capacity of the +2°C to + 8°C vaccine store is sufficient over a one year cycle. Where relevant, include other products and supplementary vaccines.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Record the make and model of all refrigeration equipment in the Notes section below, then use the EVM Assistant tool to perform the calculations. Record any equipment which is still in its packaging or has not been installed, and any equipment which is broken but repairable, but do NOT include any of this equipment in the capacity calculation. The net storage capacity is acceptable if it is greater than the estimated maximum volume of vaccine to be stored.

input.label: A. What is the net storage capacity of the +2°C to + 8°C store(s) in litres or m³.
B. What is the estimated maximum vaccine volume in litres or m³.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the EVM Assistant to perform this calculation.

input.label: C. Enter Maximum Estimated Vaccine volume (including Pentavalent vaccine) in liters or m3, plus 10% (1 month)

E3:09a. If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Using data from the vaccine delivery schedule, fixed session size data or outreach session size data, establish whether coolant pack storage capacities are sufficient to meet maximum demand levels.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Coolant packs contain either water (water-packs) or another phase change material (PCM-packs). Water packs are either frozen (ice-packs) or cooled to between +2°C and +8°C (cool-packs). PCM-packs change phase at about +5°C and eliminate the freezing risk associated with ice-packs. Record the make and model of all refrigeration equipment in the Notes section below, then use the EVM Assistant tool to perform the calculations. Record any equipment which is still in its packaging or has not been installed, and any equipment which is broken but repairable, but do NOT include any of this equipment in the capacity calculation. The net storage capacities are acceptable if they are greater than the maximum daily demands.

select1.label: A. Are conditioned ice-packs used?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Conditioned ice-packs may be used for the distribution of vaccines to lower levels, for outreach, or for on-site immunization sessions.

input.label: B. What is the available ice-pack storage capacity of all ice-pack freezers (litres)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: See the Refrig_freezer worksheet in the EVM Assistant for the coolant-pack storage capacities of freezers. If the freezer is not listed, measure the net storage capacity.

input.label: C. What is the maximum daily demand for ice-packs (litres)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the EVM Assistant to perform this calculation.

select1.label: D. Are cool-packs used?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Cool-packs may be used for the distribution of vaccines to lower levels, for outreach, or for on-site immunization sessions.

input.label: E. What is the available cool-pack storage capacity of all cool-pack refrigerators (litres)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: See the Refrig_freezer worksheet in the EVM Assistant for the coolant-pack storage capacities of refrigerators. If the refrigerator is not listed, measure the net storage capacity.

input.label: F. What is the maximum daily demand for cool-packs (litres)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the EVM Assistant to perform this calculation.

input.label: E3:10a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used. Using data from the vaccine delivery or collection schedule, or outreach session size data, establish whether there are sufficient passive containers to meet maximum demand levels.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Record the make and model of all passive containers kept at this facility in the Notes section below, then use the EVM Assistant tool to perform the calculations. The total passive container vaccine storage capacity is acceptable if it is greater than the maximum required capacity.

select1.label: A. Are passive containers kept for vaccine collection, delivery or outreach?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check whether the store is reponsible for keeping cold boxes and/or vaccine carriers, or whether these are supplied by the receiving store when vaccine is collected.

input.label: B. What is the total vaccine storage capacity of all available passive containers (litres)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: If passive containers are kept in the store, identify the type(s) and use the Passive_Containers worksheet in the EVM Assistant to find the vaccine storage capacity. If the container is not listed, measure the volume of the container with coolant-packs in place.

input.label: C. What is the maximum daily passive container vaccine storage capacity required (litres)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the EVM Assistant to perform this calculation.

input.label: E3.11a. If there is refrigeration equipment. Vaccine store contingency planning checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Contingency plans are context-specific, but should include the following minimum elements: 1) Identify the major sources of risk (e.g. power failure, flood, earthquake, etc.). 2) Prepare a written contingency plan. 3) Post emergency contact details on the noticeboard in the vaccine store. Details must be visible to passers by in case the store is locked 4) Staff must know that the universal safe storage temperature for ALL vaccines in an emergency is +2°C to +8°C.

select1.label: A. Is there a satisfactory SOP which sets out a contingency plan in the event of equipment failure or other emergency?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: 5) Identify at least two alternative cold storage locations. Inspect them to make sure they are large enough, well-managed, and can maintain correct temperatures. At sub-national stores cold boxes are not a satisfactory emergency solution.

select1.label: B. Are emergency contact details posted in the vaccine store?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: 6) Ensure that there is a written agreement with the selected emergency providers. If payment will be required, make sure that this can be funded. 7) Regularly rehearse the contingency plan with store staff and the emergency providers.

select1.label: C. Do staff know what to do in the event of an emergency?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: All staff should know what to do in the event of fire. Where relevant, staff should also know what to do in the event of temperature alarms, mains power failure and refrigerator failure. Use the Notes section to record responses.

group.label: E4 Buildings, cold chain equipment and transport systems enable the vaccine and consumables supply chain to function well

input.label: E4:03a. Vaccine store or health facility building checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Vaccine store' in this context includes service point health facilities.

select1.label: A. Is the vaccine store building suitable for the climate?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Suitable' means one of the following: 1) Cold or temperate climates: Thermally insulated and heated. 2) Hot, wet climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned. Well protected against rain penetration. 3) Hot, dry climates: Naturally ventilated or air-conditioned and/or passively protected against excessive heat build up. Protected against dust penetration.

select1.label: B. Is the roof finish in good condition and with no internal evidence of leaks?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Roof leaks': Check for damp stains on ceilings.

select1.label: C. Are the external walls free of severe cracks or other major damage?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Severe crack': A crack 5mm or greater in width which extends through the thickness of the wall. 'Major damage': Includes distortion due to subsidence or damage caused by earthquakes.

select1.label: D. Are windows and external doors in good condition and secure (grilles and/or locks)?
E. Are floors dry and reasonably level?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Reasonably level': The floor should not be visibly sloping and it should be smooth enough for small wheeled pallet trucks.

select1.label: F. Are there any fire extinguishers and have they been tested in the past 12 months?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Score n/a for small health facilities. Fire extinguishers should be tested and certified annually. There should be a label on each one showing the test date. Fire extinguishers are unlikely to be found in small health facilities, so enter 'n/a'.

select1.label: G. Is the electrical system satisfactory? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Satisfactory' means that wiring, circuit breakers, electrical sockets and light fittings are in good condition and securely fixed in place. All circuits should be properly earthed. In a full inspection the earthing of sockets can be checked with a ring main tester. If there are any doubts, a professional inspection should be carried out. Lowest delivery and service point facilities may have no electricity. If this is the case, score 'n/a'.

select1.label: H. Is the drainage system working (both rainwater and foul drainage)?
J. Is the air-conditioning system working?
select1.hint: Score 'n/a' in climates where a/c is not required

select1.label: K. Is the heating system working?
select1.hint: Score 'n/a' in climates where heating is not required

input.label: E4:13b. If there are refrigerators and/or freezers. Vaccine freezer/refrigerator checklist.

select1.label: A. Do all vaccine freezers comply with the WHO specifications that were in force at date of purchase, including correct climate zone?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check that the equipment's climate rating is correct for the site.

select1.label: B. Do all vaccine refrigerators comply with the WHO specifications that were in force at date of purchase, including correct climate zone?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Score n/a if no freezers. Check that the equipment's climate rating is correct for the site. PIS and PQS pre-qualified equipment should have a sticker to show the climate rating.

select1.label: C. Are all ice-lined refrigerators fitted with the correct vaccine storage baskets? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Score n/a if no refrigerators. Chest ILRs must always be fitted with baskets so that vaccine does not come into contact with the bottom or walls of the unit because this can freeze vaccine.

select1.label: D. For electric and solar equipment only: Are there sufficient daily hours of electricity for the installed equipment throughout the year? .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Sufficient daily hours of electricity' depends on the type of refrigeration equipment installed - >20 hrs per day for domestic and absorption units; >8 hrs per day for normal ILRs; >4 hrs per day for high efficiency ILRs. Solar systems, whether direct drive, or with batteries, must be correctly sized for the location.

select1.label: E. For kerosene and gas equipment only: Is there sufficient availability of kerosene and/or gas throughout the year? .
F. For cold climates only: Do vaccine refrigerators EITHER have low temperature protection OR are they located in a permanently heated room?
select1.hint: Score 'n/a' if low temperature protection is not required

input.label: E4:14a If there is refrigeration equipment Inspect refrigeration equipment
A. How many refrigeration units are there (dual CR and FR units count as 2, refrigerators and freezers count as 1 each)?
B. How many of these are CFC-free?
E4:15a Standby generator.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: There should always be a standby generator at the primary store unless mains electricity is completely reliable and/or has a backup supply from a separate transformer. The same requirement applies at sub-national stores equipped with cold rooms. Generators are not required in small sub-national stores, lowest delivery level and service point stores where ice-lined refrigerators are used and there is at least 8 hours electricity per day. Generators are also not required where kerosene, gas or solar refrigerators are used or where a health facility uses cold boxes or vaccine carriers for storing vaccine.

select1.label: A. Is a generator required at this store?
B. Is a standby generator installed and connected to the vaccine store?
select1.hint: Guidance Note: If a generator is installed but is not required then the generator questions are switched off and need not be answered.

input.label: E4:16a If a generator is required and installed, standby generator checklist.

select1.label: A. Is the generator in working order?
B. Does the generator have a working auto-start system?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: There should be a mains failure auto-start system so that the generator starts automatically when there is a power cut. Ideally, there should be an auto-stop system when mains power returns.

select1.label: C. Can the generator start all the connected equipment in the vaccine store?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: The starting load for a refrigeration compressor is much higher than the running load. Ask for a demonstration to prove that the generator is able to cope with the combined starting load of all connected refrigeration units. Well-designed systems may have 'smart switching' which reduces the starting load by automatically phasing in the individual refrigeration units.

select1.label: D. Is the fuel tank large enough?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: 72 hours continuous running is recommended, but this is context-dependent. If power cuts are short and/or fuel is readily available, a smaller capacity will be acceptable. The way to assess this is as follows: 1) Establish the longest power cut experienced during the review period. 2) Check the generator fuel consumption in litres per hour. 3) Check the capacity of the fuel tank. If tank capacity/consumption per hour is less than the longest power cut then the tank capacity is too small.

select1.label: E. Are there sufficient reserve supplies of fuel?
F. Is the generator in a secure compound?
E4:17a Is the voltage fluctuation sufficiently severe to require voltage regulation equipment?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Score n/a if solar refrigeration or cold boxes/vaccine carriers are used to store vaccine. Voltage regulation equipment on all refrigeration equipment is essential if voltage fluctuations exceed ±15%. Obtain information from an electrical engineer, or from the local supply company. In some settings, UPS systems (Uninterrupted Power Supply) may substitute for voltage regulators. These units also provide a limited period of back-up power.

input.label: E4:18a If voltage regulation is required, voltage regulator checklist.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: If there is no refrigeration equipment in a particular category - e.g. 'freezer room', enter 0 for the equipment number and 0 for the voltage regulator number.

input.label: A. How many freezer rooms are there?
B. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: There may be a single central voltage regulator for the vaccine store or some sharing arrangement across multiple appliances. In this case score on the basis that every piece of equipment has a regulator and make a note in the comment box.

input.label: C. How many cold rooms are there?
D. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator of the correct type?
E. How many vaccine freezers and refrigerators are there?
F. How many are attached to a functioning voltage regulator of the correct type?
input.hint: Note: Solar refrigerators do not require voltage regulators. Absorption refrigerators require a different type of voltage regulator to those used for compression refrigerators. This needs to be checked during the inspection.

input.label: E4:21b. If there are vaccine refrigerators. Temperature monitoring equipment checklist:

select1.label: A. Do all vaccine refrigerators have working continuous temperature recorders or refrigerator loggers?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Computer-connected temperature monitoring systems or 30-day refrigerator loggers are essential at PR, SN and LD levels and are highly recommended at SP level. Freeze indicators are a useful backup but they are single-use devices and they cannot identify when a freezing event occurs.

select1.label: B. Do all vaccine refrigerators have a working thermometer stored with the vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A stem or dial thermometer provides essential backup in case the continuous monitoring device fails.

select1.label: E4:24b. Are telecommunications links adequate for the facility and in working order?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Telecommunications links include fixed line telephone, fax, mobile telephone and internet. Primary and sub-national stores should have a telephone with fax and/or internet. Mobile telephones are acceptable for lower level facilities provide call costs are paid for by the programme. Radio links may be acceptable at these facilities if there is no other alternative.

select1.label: A . Answer ONLY if passive containers are kept at this facility. Do passive containers kept at this level comply with WHO specifications?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Passive containers include cold boxes, vaccine carriers and palletised or roll containers. Identify products by using the PQS or PIS catalogue.

select1.label: B. Answer ONLY if refrigerated vehicles are used. Are the disposable cartons or reusable crates used to transport vaccine fit for purpose.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: No standard set. Use judgement to assess quality. Most important is the way in which cartons or crates are packed and restrained.

group.label: E5 Maintenance of buildings, cold chain equipment and vehicles is satisfactory.

input.label: E5:01a Planned preventive maintenance checklist for buildings.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: This question is primarily about planned preventive maintenance (PPM). However, it is possible that the building is in good condition because it is being informally maintained. 01 : C covers this option.

select1.label: A. Is there a written multi-year planned preventive maintenance (PPM) programme?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: An effective planned preventive maintenance programme for buildings should cover several years into the future and should set target dates for routine maintenance such as re-decoration, electrical safety inspections, fire-extinguisher maintenance, etc.

select1.label: B. Is there documentary evidence that the programme is being followed?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: If the score to question A is 'N' then the score for Question B must also be 'N'. PPM activities should be monitored and recorded.

select1.label: C. Is there visual evidence that maintenance is taking place?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: If an effective maintenance programme is in place, the building should be in good condition. Indicators of poor building maintenance include broken light bulbs, leaks and damp stains, blocked drains, flaking paintwork, etc. See answers to E4:04a.

input.label: E5:02a If there is refrigeration equipment, Planned preventive maintenance checklist for refrigeration equipment.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: In this context, 'planned preventive maintenance' (PPM) is as set out in the cold chain equipment manufacturers' service manuals. Both the need for and the timing of PPM can be foreseen.

select1.label: A. Is there a written planned preventive maintenance (PPM) programme.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: An effective planned preventive maintenance programme for buildings should preferably cover several years into the future and should set target dates for routine maintenance such as re-decoration, electrical safety inspections, fire-extinguisher maintenance, etc. Some countries have annual plans and budgets.

select1.label: B. Is there documentary evidence that the programme is being followed.
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: PPM should be recorded in a maintenance record book or worksheet.

select1.label: C. Is somebody assigned to carry out routine maintenance
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A permanent member of the facility staff must be formally assigned to carry out the tasks below. They should not be left to ancillary staff such as cleaners.

select1.label: D. Is there evidence that cold rooms/refrigerators/ freezers have recently been cleaned and defrosted?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check for excessive ice accumulation on evaporator units or the inside lining. Ice accumulation or condensation along the panel joints in cold rooms and freezer rooms is a sign that panel joints are leaking or poorly designed.

select1.label: E. If kerosene refrigerators are used, is there evidence that the wicks have been trimmed and chimneys cleaned?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Frequent trimming and replacement of wicks in kerosene refrigerators is absolutely essential. Chimneys also need to be cleaned regularly, especially if kerosene quality is poor.

select1.label: F. If solar refrigerators are used, are all solar panels clean and completely unshaded by buildings, trees and overhead cables?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Shading seriously degrades solar panel performance. Shading problems can increase over the years following the original installation as trees grow, new buildings are built and new overhead cables are erected. All solar panels should be cleaned from time to time to maintain efficiency. This is particularly important in dusty areas and in countries where there is snow.

select1.label: G. If battery powered solar refrigerators are used, is there evidence that the battery electrolyte has been checked recently?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Some flooded batteries are not sealed and require regular checking of electrolyte levels and topping up with battery acid.

input.label: E5:05b. If vaccine is stored at the facility AND there are refrigerators/freezers. Vaccine refrigerator and vaccine freezer maintenance checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Include all vaccine refrigerators and freezers in the store, unless it is clear that broken units are genuinely being kept for spare parts or disposal.

input.label: A. How many vaccine refrigerators and vaccine freezers are there (all types, including solar)?
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Ignore equipment that has been officially decommissioned. Include any equipment that is temporarily switched off because it is not needed. Check that it operates.

input.label: B. How many were fully operational at the time of inspection?
input.hint: GuidanceNotes: Check if the unit has been out of operation for more than 7 days. If so, record this in the notes box. With kerosene units, check that the burner has been assembled correctly.

input.label: C. Of the non-functional units, how many have been out of use for more than four weeks? Describe the reason(s) for this in the notes.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: A delay of four weeks or more for a repair is unacceptable. A well-managed maintenance system, should aim to repair appliances within one week of breakdown.

input.label: E5.06b. If there are dedicated ice-pack freezers or cool-pack coolers. Maintenance checklist for equipment used only for freezing ice-packs or cooling cool-packs:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Include all units in the store unless it is clear that broken units are genuinely being kept for spare parts or disposal.

input.label: A. How many ice-pack freezers/cool-pack coolers are there?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Ignore equipment that has been officially decommissioned. Include any equipment that is temporarily switched off because it is not needed. Check that it operates.

input.label: B. How many were fully operational at the time of inspection?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Check if the unit has been out of operation for more than 7 days. If so, record this in the notes box.

input.label: C. Of the non-functional units, how many have been out of use for more than four weeks? Describe the reason(s) for this in the notes.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: A delay of four weeks or more for a repair is unacceptable. A well-managed maintenance system, should aim to repair appliances within one week of breakdown.

group.label: E6 Stock management systems and procedures are effective.

select1.label: E6:03a Are all vaccine arrivals and vaccine dispatches recorded and stock balances updated within one working day of the transaction?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : The practice of batch processing arrival and delivery slips should be discouraged because it leads to out of date stock records.

input.label: E6:04a Do the stock records record the following information for all vaccines.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: The stock recording system may be paper-based or computerized. If diluents are packed with the vaccine, they need not be recorded separately.

select1.label: A. Type of vaccine
B. Vaccine presentation (vial size)
C. Quantity received in doses
D. Vaccine manufacturer
E. Manufacturing batch or lot number
F. Expiry date of each vaccine batch
G. VVM status where applicable
H. Location in the store
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : A record of location in the store is essential at primary level and in larger sub-national stores. It is unnecessary in small sub-national stores and at health facility level.

input.label: E6:05a Do the stock records record the following information for all diluents that are packed separately from the vaccine to which they belong.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: The stock recording system may be paper-based or computerized. If diluents are packed with the vaccine, they need not be recorded separately.

select1.label: A. Type of diluent
B. Diluent presentation (vial size)
C. Quantity received in doses
D. Diluent manufacturer
E. Manufacturing batch or lot number
F. Expiry date of each batch
G. Location in the store
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : A record of location in the store is essential at primary level and in larger sub-national stores. It is unnecessary in small sub-national stores and in health facilities.

select1.label: E6:07a Are vaccine requisition forms used for ordering and receiving vaccine?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : See model SOP on requisitioning for guidance on good practice. Assess content of existing form(s) against the content of the model forms.

input.label: E6:08b. Pre-delivery/pre-collection notification system checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Effective' means that the system is understood and used by the receiving stores and that deliveries or collections are reliably made on or near a day that has been arranged well in advance.

select1.label: A. Is there a formal advanced notification process to advise receiving stores of the time of vaccine delivery/collection
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Advanced notification should be received at least 24 hours before the expected time of arrival of the delivery.

select1.label: B. Is the notification process followed?
E6:10a Can the storekeeper make exceptions to the EEFO rule (e.g. because of VVM status)?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : If VVMs on later-dated stock show Stage 2 exposure whilst early-dated stock is still at Stage 1, the heat-exposed later-dated stock should generally be issued first.

input.label: E6:15b If vaccine is stored at the facility, checklist for management of damaged or expired stock.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

select1.label: A. Is the stock control system designed to record vaccine and diluent wastage due to expiry, freezing or heat-exposure?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : If vaccine has to be discarded, any associated diluent must also be discarded. Failure to do this can lead to a stockpile of 'orphaned' diluent.

select1.label: B. SP LEVEL ONLY: Is the stock control system designed to record vaccine and diluent wastage in opened vials?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : If the stock records show that there have been no losses during the review period, ask the storekeeper to confirm whether or not this is true.

select1.label: C. If the stock control system records wastage in unopened and/or opened vials, do the records and other on-site evidence show that the system is being used?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: If vaccine is lost, the storekeeper may suffer personal penalties unless the country operates a 'no blame' policy. For this reason, honest reporting may not take place. Carefully check the stock inside and outside the cold chain equipment to see if there are containers with discarded vials. Also use the temperature records to see if there have been long periods of excessively low or high temperature - see E2. Are any waste reports to Government found for the last five years?

select1.label: D. Do staff know that expired and damaged vaccine should be clearly labelled and stored out of the cold chain until final disposal?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Damaged vaccine must be clearly labelled and stored outside the cold chain to prevent it being issued in error.

input.label: E6:16a If there is a functioning system for recording damaged or expired vaccine, select a freeze-sensitive vaccine. Establish how many doses have been discarded during the review period due to freezing or exposure to high temperature.
input.hint: Carry out this check even if the storekeeper reports that no vaccine has been lost. A score of 5 is only achieved if the percentage of vaccine lost is no more than 1% of the doses issued during the review period. Exposure to freezing must have been confirmed by a shake test. Exposure to high temperature must have been confirmed by VVM colour changes.

select1.label: A. Enter choice of vaccine:

input.label: B. Record number of doses of chosen vaccine issued during the review period.
C. Record number of doses of chosen vaccine discarded because of incorrect storage temperatures.
input.hint: Guidance Notes : This indicator can only be assessed if stock records are accurate, informative and truthful. If there is no method to record vaccine damage, the score is 0.

select1.label: E6:17a Are disposal facilities and procedures in accordance with WHO and/or national norms?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Refer to Guidelines for Safe Disposal of Unwanted Pharmaceuticals in and after Emergencies. WHO/EDM/PAR/99.2

select1.label: E6:18a Have records of discarded vaccine been kept for at least three years, or, if for a lesser period, since the immunization programme adopted the EVSM or EVM?
E6:19a Are internal reviews of the vaccine loss/damage records carried out at least twice a year?

input.label: E6:20b. If vaccine is stored at the facility. Assess stock level policy:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the stock records to assess whether the store held excessive and/or insufficient stock during the review period.

select1.label: A. Is a maximum stock level set for each vaccine and commodity?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A maximum stock level should be set to control over-stocking. Overstocking makes store management difficult and increases the risk of expiry.

select1.label: B. Is a reorder level set for each vaccine and commodity?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A reorder level is needed to take account of delivery lead-time so that safety stocks are not breached.

select1.label: C. Is a safety (minimum) stock level set for each vaccine and commodity?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: A safety stock level needs to be set to reduce the risk of stockouts.

select1.label: D. Can responsible staff explain the concepts of maximum stock, safety stock and reorder level?
E. If a maximum stock level is set for DTP containing vaccine, did the stock of this vaccine remain below the maximum level throughout the review period?
select1.hint: Note: This calculation CANNOT be done unless a maximum stock level has been set. You may use Worksheet B in the EVM Assistant. The calculation includes an addition of 10% to the store's defined maximum stock level to allow for supply fluctuations.

select1.label: F. If a minimum stock level is set for DTP containing vaccine, did the stock of this vaccine remain above the minimum level throughout the review period?
select1.hint: Note: This calculation CANNOT be done unless a minimum stock level has been set. You may use Worksheet B in the EVM Assistant. The calculation includes a deduction of 10% from the store's defined minimum stock level to allow for supply fluctuations.

input.label: E6:21a. If vaccine is stored at the facility. Assess adequacy of annual supply of DTP containing vaccine:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use the stock records to assess whether the annual supply of DTP containing vaccine was sufficient to meet forecasted demand.

input.label: A. What is the forecasted demand (doses) for DTP containing vaccine for the review period?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: The forecasted demand may be found in the facility annual plan. The national immunization programme determines the forecasting method.

input.label: B. What is the total quantity (doses) of DTP containing vaccine received during the review period?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: The total quantity of vaccine received is adequate if it is equal to or greater than the forecasted demand.

input.label: E6:22a If vaccine is stored at this facility, Physical inventory frequency checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

input.label: A. Enter the planned vaccine supply period, in months
B. Enter number of recorded physical counts of vaccine stocks carried out during the 12 month review period
input.hint: Guidance Notes: All stores should carry out a physical count at least 4 times a year. Lower level stores and health facilities should carry out a count at the time of each incoming delivery (for Push systems) or at the time of each order request (for Pull systems).

input.label: E6:23b. If vaccine is stored at the facility. Choose a sample freeze-dried vaccine and diluent.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: This question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers. The following checks are carried out:

select1.label: A. Enter choice of vaccine:

input.label: B. Carry out a physical count of the sample vaccine. Enter number of doses counted:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: At service point level it is useful and generally easy to count and record all vaccines and diluents. These data can be used to demonstrate how well-balanced stocks are at the point of use.

input.label: C. Carry out a physical count of the sample diluent. Enter number of doses counted:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: 1) DO NOT count vaccine at or beyond the VVM discard point. If the adjusted vaccine count differs from the diluent count by >±1% a 'Mismatch' message appears. Otherwise a 'Match' message appears.

input.label: D. Check stock records for sample vaccine. Enter number of doses recorded as currently in stock:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: 2) If the vaccine stock records = the vaccine count an '=' sign appears. If they are different, the warning 'Not =' appears.

input.label: E. Check stock records for sample diluent. Enter number of doses recorded as currently in stock:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: 3) If the diluent stock records = the diluent count an '=' sign appears. If they are different, the warning 'Not =' appears.

input.label: F. How many doses are at the VVM discard point or beyond?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Discard point': When the inner square matches, or is darker than, the colour of the outer circle. Adjust score downwards if you find examples in your sample.

input.label: G. Scoring: Score 4 if stock count and records match exactly AND vaccine and diluent quantities are within 1% of one another AND no VVMs are at the discard point (see results). Use your judgement to adjust the score between 0 and 4.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Scoring: Ideally, the physical count and the stock records should always match at the end of the working day. However, there may be discrepancies during the day if the stock records are not updated immediately; check with the storekeeper. There are legitimate reasons why diluent quantities may differ from vaccine quantities. One of these is that vaccine manufacturers sometimes over-supply diluent. Therefore, if there is slightly more diluent than vaccine, there may be no problem. If there is much more, or much less diluent, than vaccine, there must be a problem.

input.label: E6:24a. If consumables are held in this store. Choose a sample consumable. Enter it in the box below :

select1.label: A. Enter choice of consumable:

input.label: B. Carry out a physical count of the sample consumable. Enter number of items counted:
C. Check stock records for sample consumable. Enter number of items recorded as currently in stock:
D. Scoring: Score 4 if stock count and records match exactly. Use your judgement to adjust the score between 4 and 0 for mismatches.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Scoring: Ideally, the physical count and the stock records should always match at the end of the working day. However, there may be discrepancies during the day if the stock records are not updated immediately; check with the storekeeper. There are legitimate reasons why diluent quantities may differ from vaccine quantities. One of these is that vaccine manufacturers sometimes over-supply diluent. Therefore, if there is slightly more diluent than vaccine, there may be no problem. If there is much more, or much less diluent, than vaccine, there must be a problem.

input.label: E6:25b. If vaccine is stored at the facility. Checklist for vaccine storage arrangements:
input.hint: Guidance Notes : Question does not apply if there is no refrigerated storage at the facility. For example, at health facilities using cold boxes and vaccine carriers.

select1.label: A. Is the vaccine stock secure?
B. Are contents labels fixed to all cold chain equipment indicating vaccine type, lot no. and expiry date .
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check for labels on the lid of refrigerators and freezers, or on the edge of the shelves in freezer rooms and cold rooms. Score 'n/a' where labelling is not needed. Labels are not required at health facility level unless there are several refrigerators.

select1.label: C. Are vaccines correctly stored?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: No freeze-sensitive vaccines stored close to cold room evaporators, stored close to the ice lining in ILRs or stored close to the evaporator plate of service point refrigerators. No vaccines should be kept in the door shelves of domestic refrigerators.

select1.label: D. Is vaccine laid out in in EEFO order, by type and by lot number?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Ask which vaccines of a particular type are going to be picked first and check whether these items have the shortest expiry date.

select1.label: E. Is the vaccine store clean, dry and pest-free?

input.label: E6:26a If consumables are held in this store, checklist for dry storage arrangements.

select1.label: A. Are dry goods secure?
B. Are dry goods correctly stored?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Correct' means that stocks should be neatly stacked on pallets so that they are accessible and are not affected by floor washing.

select1.label: C. Are dry goods laid out in an orderly fashion and in EEFO order where applicable?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Syringes have expiry dates and must therefore be organised in EEFO order. Ask which stock is going to be picked first and check whether these items have the shortest expiry date.

select1.label: D. Is the dry store clean, dry and pest-free?
E6:27a Are the records secure?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Records should be stored in lockable filing cabinets.

group.label: E7 - Distribution between each level in the supply chain is effective.

input.label: E7:06a If cold boxes or other passive containers are used, assess knowledge of coolant preparation and packing of cold boxes, vaccine carriers and other passive containers.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Ask whether a systematic temperature monitoring, or journey profiling, study has been carried out. Coolant preparation includes ice-pack conditioning, preparation of cool-packs/PCM-packs and preparation of special coolant-packs for palletized or wheeled passive containers.

select1.label: A. Do staff carry out ice-pack conditioning or cool-pack preparation is in accordance with WHO guidelines?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: For palletized or wheeled containers, follow the manufacturer's instructions.

select1.label: B. Is packing in accordance with appliance labelling or SOP?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Cold boxes, vaccine carriers and other passive containers are designed to suit a particular size of coolant-pack. Sometimes the correct size is not available. In such circumstances it is essential that store staff know what to do.

select1.label: E7:08a Cold climates only. Do staff know how to prevent vaccine freezing during transport?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : Refer to SOP on freeze prevention for details.

select1.label: E7:09a. Are freeze indicators required for the transport of freeze-sensitive vaccines?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Freeze indicators are NOT required if cool-packs or PCM-packs are always used in passive containers and there is no risk of freezing in winter months. Freeze indicators MAY be required when vaccine is transported in refrigerated vehicles with poor temperature control or limited monitoring equipment. Freeze indicators ARE required when freeze-sensitive vaccines are packed with frozen ice-packs, even if these have been conditioned. They are also recommended in very cold climates where warm-packs are needed to prevent vaccine freezing during transport. Cool-packs should be kept for at least 24 hrs at a temperature between +2°C and +8°C. PCM-packs must be prepared as instructed by the PCM-pack manufacturer.

input.label: E7:10a. If freeze indicators are required. Were freeze indicators packed with deliveries of freeze-sensitive vaccines during the review period? Scoring: Score on a scale of 0-4 where 4 indicates that freeze indicators were used on all deliveries and 0 indicates that they were never used.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: If freeze indicators are used, there must be an effective zero-reporting system to record the state of the freeze indicator on arrival at the receiving store. Scoring: Score on a scale of 0-4 where 4 indicates that freeze indicators were used on all deliveries, 3 indicates that they were used on more than 2/3rds of deliveries, 2 indicates that they were used on 1/3rd to 2/3rds of deliveries, 1 indicates that they were used on less that 1/3rd of deliveries, and 0 indicates they were not used on any deliveries.

select1.label: A. Is there a written outreach programme?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Date and destination of all outreach activities should be recorded. This information can be compared with the programme.

input.label: B. How many outreach activities were planned in the review period?
C. How many of these planned activities took place?

group.label: E8 - Appropriate vaccine management policies are adopted and implemented.

input.label: E8:01a. If vaccine is stored at the facility. Assess knowledge of the shake test:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: This question is not applicable at health facility level in situations where there is no refrigerator

select1.label: A. Does the storekeeper or health worker know how to conduct the shake test?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check knowledge against the Shake test learning guide

select1.label: B. Does the storekeeper or health worker know when to conduct the shake test?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check knowledge against the Shake test learning guide

select1.label: C. Has the storekeeper of health worker carried out a shake test in the last 12 months?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Only score n/a if you are sure that there were no events in the review period that required a shake test.

select1.label: E8:02b. Use of freeze-dried vaccines and their diluents during immunization sessions. Is the correct diluent always used to reconstitute freeze-dried vaccines?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: If direct observation during an immunization session is not possible, ask the health worker to show you which vaccine belongs to which diluent. Ask what s/he would do if there was vaccine without diluent. If s/he says that s/he would use diluent from another type of vaccine, this is wrong. Recording of diluent and vaccine lot numbers and matching of diluent and vaccine quantities during storage is covered in E6.

select1.label: E8:03b. Diluent management practices at the health facility. Are diluents always kept in the cold chain before and during every immunization session?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: If direct observation of this practice is not possible, ask the health worker where diluents are kept before and during immunization sessions.

select1.label: E8:04b. Discarding opened vials of freeze-dried vaccines at the end of the session. Are opened vials of freeze-dried vaccines discarded within the period stated in the national immunization policy?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: WHO recommendation is within six hours of reconstitution, or at the end of each immunization session, whichever comes first. National guidance may allow fewer hours, but never more. If direct observation of this practice is not possible, ask the health worker when opened vials of freeze-dried vaccine are discarded, and compare the response to the national policy.

select1.label: E8:05a. Are written instructions on the use of VVMs, such as posters and stickers, available to storekeepers and health workers?
E8:06a. Do storekeepers/health workers know how to read VVMs?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Use dummy VVMs and/or sticker samples to check knowledge. To score 'Y', all those responsible in the facility must know that vaccines at or beyond the discard point must not be used (inner square as dark as or darker than the outer circle) and also that vaccines with VVMs closest to the discard point must be used first.

select1.label: E8:07a. Are the VVMs on all vaccines in the health facility refrigerator, cold box or vaccine carrier before the discard point?
E8:08a. Do store keepers/health workers use VVM status for vaccine management purposes (e.g. do they use Stage 2 vaccines first)?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check health worker knowledge using the following method. Sample 1: a stage 1 VVM on an short expiry date vial; Sample 2: a stage 2 VVM on a long expiry date vial. Ask which one should be used first. The correct answer is Sample 2.

select1.label: E8:09a Has the MDVP been adopted?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Verify this by inspecting written instructions. The correct implementation of MDVP is for the country to determine and some choose not to do so. Others may modify WHO guidance. For example, five days maximum after opening is a rule adopted by some. In this example, keeping for up to 5 days is correct; keeping for more than 5 days is incorrect, even though WHO guidance allows up to 28 days.

select1.label: E8:10a If MDVP has been adopted, Can health workers explain how to apply the MDVP?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes : This question only applies if MDVP has been adopted.

input.label: E8:11b. If MDVP has been adopted.
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Ask health workers to show which opened vials they will use for the next session and verify this information through immunization records.

select1.label: A. Are there opened vials of liquid vaccine in the refrigerator?
B. If there are opened vials in the refrigerator, are they all marked with the dates of opening?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Date of original opening should be marked on the vial.

select1.label: C. If there are opened vials marked with the dates of opening, are the dates all no more than 28 days before today's date?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check that no opened vials have been kept for longer than the period stated in national policy, or 28 days if WHO guidance is followed.

select1.label: E8:12b. Do immunization reports and/or other standard reporting forms contain data that can be used to calculate the vaccine wastage at the facility?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: At national level this question should be addressed to the EPI Manager. At lower level stores wastage rates may not be calculated. However, the information needed for the calculation should be collected and reported up the supply chain. For example, number of children immunized, doses used and doses lost, destroyed or expired.

input.label: E8:13b Wastage calculation checklist:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: At national level this question should be addressed to the EPI Manager.

select1.label: A. Can the storekeeper/health worker at PR, SN, LD and SP levels correctly explain the main types of unopened vial wastage? At SP level, can the health worker also explain the main types of opened vial wastage?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Unopened vial wastage': PR, SN, LD and SP: Expiry; VVM exposure; Freezing; Breakage; Theft or missing inventory. SP only: Unopened vials returned from outreach. 'Opened vial wastage': SP only: Discard at end of session; Incorrect reconstitution; Suspected contamination (e.g. opened vial submerged in water); Patient reaction requiring more than one dose.

select1.label: B. Can the responsible person explain how the wastage rate is calculated?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: The assessor needs to understand the correct calculation method for PR, SN and LD levels and the correct method of calculation at SP level. Refer to the formulae in paragraphs 2.2 and 2.3 of the following reference document.

select1.label: C. For the review period, is there a complete set of wastage rate data or a complete set of data that can be used for calculating wastage rates?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2003/WHO_V&B_03.18.pdf

select1.label: D. If there is a complete set of data, is there evidence that the data are used to monitor vaccine management performance?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Score n/a if the facility collects the data to calculate wastage, but is not directly responsible for wastage rate calculations.

input.label: E8:15b. Syringe and vial disposal checklist:

select1.label: A. Is there a sufficient number of safety boxes (or containers for de-fanged syringes and cut needles) in stock?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: There should be a sufficient number of safety boxes in stock to last until the next scheduled delivery. If needle cutters are used, there should be a sufficient number of suitable containers for cut needles and de-fanged syringes.

select1.label: B. If safety boxes are used, is there an assembled safety box in the immunization room?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Check if a box is in place in the immunization room and if it contains used syringes.

select1.label: C. Is there an effective waste segregation system?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Filled safety boxes (or needle containers) and used vials must be stored in a safe place pending final disposal.

select1.label: D. Is there a safe method of waste disposal, either on-site or off-site
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Safe methods' include high temperature incineration, steam sterilization or scheduled removal from site to properly regulated disposal facility. Burial on site in a securely fenced off pit is acceptable only if well-controlled.

select1.label: E. Is the site compound free of used syringes, needles and vials
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Walk round the compound and check for used syringes, needles and vials.

select1.label: F. If there is a high temperature on-site incinerator or a waste sterilizer, is it fitted with a working temperature indicator?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: High temperature' means operation between 650°C and 1,200°C. Burning in an uncontrolled low temperature incinerator or a pit is never acceptable.

group.label: Information systems and supportive management functions are satisfactory.

input.label: E9:07a. Checklist for vaccine needs forecasting:
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Use one of the options described in the Mid-level Management training series. Namely: 1) At primary and sub-national levels: Target population or previous consumption data. 2) At service point level: Session size. Check to ensure that there is compatibility/convergence with the method used in developing the country's comprehensive multi-year plan (cMYP).

select1.label: A. Is a standard method used to estimate annual vaccine need?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Standard method' means the UNICEF vaccine forecasting tool or equivalent. 'Evidence-based' means that data have been systematically collected - for example national population census, updated as necessary.

select1.label: B. Is evidence-based target population data used in the calculation?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Calculations can be based on target population data and assumed vaccine wastage rates, but it is much better to use evidence-based wastage data collected from the field.

select1.label: C. Is evidence-based coverage data used in the calculation?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Coverage data will generally be taken from the routine reporting system. Ideally these data should be verified by periodic coverage surveys.

select1.label: D. Is evidence-based vaccine wastage data used in the calculation?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Calculations can be based on target population data, coverage data and assumed vaccine wastage rates, but it is much better to use evidence-based wastage data collected from the field.

input.label: E9:08a. Checklist for safe injection equipment needs forecasting:

select1.label: A. Is a standard method used to estimate annual need for syringes and safety boxes?
B. Is evidence-based target population data used in the calculation?
C. Is evidence-based coverage data used in the calculation?
A. Did the storekeeper/health worker receive on-the-job or classroom training in vaccine management during the review period?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Use Notes to describe any training received.

select1.label: B. Are there records of training given?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: There should be a training record of some kind. This could be a certificate of attendance for a classroom course or copies of guidance notes used during on-the-job training.

input.label: A. How many supervisory visits did the facility recieve during the review period?
input.hint: Guidance Notes: Supportive supervision should take place at least once per quarter.

select1.label: B. Are there records of supportive supervision?
select1.hint: Guidance Notes: Supportive supervision visits should be logged in a log book or visitor book.
